description: German Expressionism. The picture encloses four figures in a tight, absurd configuration defined by a picture frame and a door frame. Two men dressed as harlequins raise a daringly balanced woman muffled up in winter attire. A waiter in tails with a tray full of champagne glasses slides between the figures. In the background is a broad sky, low-lying snow covered mountains, and two figures in a horse costume.

marks: Signature and Date LL in black: [Beckmann 32]
provenance:
Max Beckmann [1884-1950], Germany, New York, New York, and St. Louis, Missouri; (Curt Valentin, Buchholz Gallery, New York, New York in 1949);[1] Putnam Dana McMillan [d.1961], Minneapolis, Minnesota on October 7, 1949;[2] bequest to MIA on November 15, 1961.

[1] Letter in curatorial file from Curt Valentin states, "â¦it was always the property of the artist himself until I sold it to Mr. McMillan. The picture was painted in Germany in 1932 when Max Beckmann was still in Germany."

[2] Putnam Dana McMillan was the vice president of General Mills.
title: The Skaters
